title: Twitter tirades, drug use and legal trouble: Welcome to the NHL
text:
Fantasy Fare: Three days of surprises 
A Twitter tirade, tales of drug use, run-ins with the law, landmark suspensions - welcome to the 2015-16 National Hockey League season. 
Here we are, on the first weekend in what will be a six month marathon to the Stanley Cup playoffs, and already the league is shrouded with controversy on a number of fronts, including issues that, on the surface, would seem to be more relevant fodder for CNN than TSN. 
From Mike Richards to Mike Commodore to Aaron Ward to Patrick Kane , here are some news and views on some of the more pressing matters in the world of hockey. 
FREE FALL FROM GRACE 
Hearing the stunning comments from Kings GM Dean Lombardi this week to the LA Times regarding Mike Richards provided yet another example of how quickly someone can go from the top of the world to the bottom of the barrel. 
Having known Richards since his junior days in Kitchener, one memory stands out as a reminder of the type of person many of us knew him to be before troubled times took over. 
Less than two weeks after inking his mammoth 12-year, $69 million US deal with the Flyers on Dec. 13, 2007, Richards flew back home to Kenora for the NHL’s brief holiday break armed with a surprise for his father. When his dad woke up on Christmas morning and looked in the driveway of the family home, there was a brand new pickup truck waiting for him in the driveway courtesy of Santa Mike. 
A lot has happened since that time. Here’s hoping he gets the help he requires to straighten out his life which, as underscored by Lombardi’s comments, he obviously needs to do. 
Lombardi said that that Richards’ fall from grace is “the most traumatic episode of my career,” adding “at times, I think that I will never recover from it.” 
“I heard the rumors that Mike might have some off-ice issues, but I refused to believe that they were true despite some obvious signs,” Lombardi wrote to Times. “The reality is that I was ‘played.’ My only regret, though, is that I wish Mike had been able to come to me with his problem — and that was the last message I left for him on his cellphone when I learned of the incident and all the history leading up to the incident.” 
“Anyone close enough to me knows how much I loved Mike Richards,” Lombardi added. “I believed that when I had acquired him, I had found my own Derek Jeter. But the fact is that he was never close to the player that he was after his best seasons in 2008-09 and 2009-10 in Philadelphia. His production dropped 50% and the certain ‘it’ factor he had was vaporizing in front of me daily.” 
Sad. 
BLACK FRIDAY 
On Friday afternoon the news came down that authorities had arrested TSN analyst Aaron Ward following a domestic incident. Captain Don Hamilton with the Cary (N.C.) Police Department said Ward had been brought into custody after police responded to a call concerning a domestic assault. Ward was charged with assault on a female and interfering with emergency communications, both misdemeanors. Hamilton said authorities initially cited Ward’s wife, Kelly, for misdemeanor simple assault on him, but they rescinded the citation after further investigation, and she faces no charges. 
Hours later, former Red Wing Mike Commodore’s Twitter account featured an obscenity-laced tirade against Leafs coach Mike Babcock . 
All this on Day 3 of the new season. 
LAST MINUTE OF PLAY 
Meanwhile, there was the road reaction to Hawks star Patrick Kane , who was greeted by chants of “No Means No” by Islanders fans at Brooklyn’s Barkley Center. 
Kane had best brace himself. Because this won’t be the last time he gets mocked by opposing crowds around the league. 
Interesting, if not troubling times, in the first week of the NHL season. 
mike.zeisberger@sunmedia.ca
